breakingNews.text: üî• POST-CEASEFIRE ANALYSIS: Iran threatens NPT withdrawal, can restart enrichment within months

gameTheoryNote.title: üéØ Game Theory Update: "Temporary Retreat" Dynamics
gameTheoryNote.description: Strategic Shift: The 12-day war ended in a fragile ceasefire, but both sides are now in a "temporary retreat" phase. Iran's nuclear program was damaged but not destroyed, creating a new chicken game dynamic where Iran must decide whether to openly pursue nuclear weapons or rebuild covertly. Israel faces the dilemma of whether to accept this temporary setback or prepare for another round.

poll.question: Which scenario is most likely over the next 12 months? (Post-ceasefire probabilities)

options.title: Covert Nuclear Reconstruction
options.description: Iran secretly rebuilds while maintaining diplomatic facade

options.title: Open Nuclear Breakout
options.description: Iran exits NPT and rushes to weapons capability

options.title: Status Quo with Periodic Tensions
options.description: Fragile ceasefire holds without major escalation

scenarios.description: Post-War Game Theory Assessment: Iran's nuclear program was damaged but not eliminated, creating new strategic dynamics. Iran faces a choice between covert reconstruction (high probability) or open breakout (high risk). Israel must decide whether to accept temporary victory or prepare for round two. The ceasefire has created a temporary equilibrium, but underlying dynamics remain explosive.
scenarios.chartLegend: Updated Methodology: Post-conflict analysis incorporating actual damage assessments, Iranian response patterns, IAEA monitoring gaps, and revised intelligence estimates of nuclear reconstruction timelines.

items.title: Covert Nuclear Reconstruction
items.description: Most Likely: Iran pursues clandestine nuclear program rebuilding while maintaining diplomatic facade. Intelligence suggests 3-6 month reconstruction timeline for basic enrichment capabilities. Iran's IAEA suspension creates monitoring blind spots.

items.title: Open Nuclear Breakout
items.description: High Risk: Iran exits NPT and openly pursues nuclear weapons. Triggered by perceived Israeli preparation for second strike or regime survival concerns. Would guarantee renewed military conflict within months.

items.title: Renewed Diplomatic Engagement
items.description: Diplomatic Window: EU-mediated negotiations resume, potentially including US-Iran bilateral talks. Success depends on Iranian willingness to accept enhanced monitoring in exchange for sanctions relief and security guarantees.

items.title: Israeli Preventive Strike 2.0
items.description: Preemptive Logic: Israel strikes again within 6-12 months if intelligence confirms nuclear reconstruction. Higher probability if Iran exits NPT or enrichment levels spike. US support uncertain for second round.

items.title: Status Quo Maintenance
items.description: Unstable Equilibrium: Current ceasefire holds without major escalation. Low probability due to underlying nuclear timeline pressures and mutual strategic mistrust. Requires sustained diplomatic management.

riskCalculator.intro: Post-Ceasefire Risk Assessment: The 12-day war created new strategic realities but didn't resolve underlying nuclear crisis. Iran's program was damaged but not eliminated, creating unstable equilibrium. Adjust factors below to model post-conflict dynamics.

escalationAnalysis.title: ‚ö†Ô∏è Post-War Escalation Dynamics
escalationAnalysis.description: Current Risk Level: Higher than pre-war due to demonstrated willingness to use force, nuclear program damage but not elimination, and collapsed diplomatic frameworks. Iran's IAEA suspension creates intelligence gaps that increase miscalculation risks.

timeline.description: Post-ceasefire critical decision points that will determine whether fragile peace holds or conflict resumes

events.title: üî¨ Nuclear Reconstruction Assessment
events.description: Intelligence Window: First assessments of Iranian nuclear reconstruction efforts. IAEA monitoring gaps create uncertainty. Israeli intelligence capabilities will be crucial in determining whether Iran is rebuilding covertly or openly.

events.title: üá™üá∫ European Mediation Initiative
events.description: Diplomatic Opportunity: EU-led effort to restart nuclear negotiations before Iranian capabilities are fully restored. Success depends on Iranian willingness to accept enhanced monitoring and Israeli restraint guarantees.

events.title: ‚öñÔ∏è Decision Point: Diplomacy vs. Action
events.description: Strategic Crossroads: If diplomacy fails and Iranian nuclear reconstruction accelerates, Israel faces decision on second preventive strike. US support uncertain, making timing critical.

events.title: üéØ Final Escalation or Stabilization
events.description: End Game: Either successful diplomatic framework establishing new nuclear constraints, or renewed military conflict as Iran approaches nuclear threshold. Winter energy concerns may force resolution.

tickerHeadlines: POST-CEASEFIRE: Iran can restart uranium enrichment within months according to IAEA chief
INTELLIGENCE ASSESSMENT: US strikes set back Iran's nuclear program by months, not years
DIPLOMATIC WINDOW: EU calls for immediate restart of nuclear negotiations
STRATEGIC THREAT: Iran threatens to exit NPT if diplomatic pressure continues
MONITORING CRISIS: Iran's IAEA suspension creates intelligence blind spots
RECONSTRUCTION TIMELINE: Iranian nuclear facilities show signs of rapid repair efforts
ISRAELI POSITION: Netanyahu keeps military option open for 'second round' if needed
TRUMP DILEMMA: President weighs diplomatic engagement vs. military support for Israel
REGIONAL STABILITY: Gulf states push for mediated solution to prevent energy crisis
NUCLEAR PROLIFERATION: Experts warn Iran may accelerate covert weapons program
